requirements.title: Define ODD Parameters
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper, p. 54, 223
requirements.raw_text: The AI/ML system shall operate only within a defined and validated Operational Design Domain (ODD) whose parameters are explicitly specified, versioned, and approved.

requirements.title: ODD Coverage Assurance (ISO/PAS 21448)
requirements.source_citation: ISO/PAS 21448 (SOTIF)
requirements.raw_text: The dataset used for development and verification shall sufficiently and representatively cover the defined ODD, including edge cases identified by hazard analysis.

requirements.title: Data Quality Requirements (DQR)
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper, p. 57, 61
requirements.raw_text: Data used across the lifecycle shall meet documented quality requirements for relevance, origin, format, accuracy, traceability, integrity, completeness, and representativeness

requirements.title: Data Verification & Validation
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper, p. 64, 168
requirements.raw_text: The organization shall verify and validate data against the DQRs, producing objective evidence that completeness and representativeness criteria are satisfied before training.

requirements.title: FAA/EASA Dataset Separation
requirements.source_citation: FAA Research Plan: research plan assumptions 9 page 17 and EASA Concept page 202
requirements.raw_text: Training, validation, test, and certification holdout datasets shall be strictly separated, with controls preventing cross-contamination.

requirements.title: FDA Dataset Separation
requirements.source_citation: FDA Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Discussion Paper page 9
requirements.raw_text: The data pipeline shall prevent any leakage between training, tuning, and testing splits, with auditable safeguards and checks.

requirements.title: Identify Security Risks (IS-01/02)
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper, p. 141
requirements.raw_text: Information security risks, including AI/ML?specific threats, shall be identified, assessed, and recorded with explicit linkage to mitigations.

requirements.title: Validate Security Controls (IS-03)
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper, p. 141
requirements.raw_text: Security controls addressing AI/ML?specific risks shall be verified and validated for effectiveness prior to deployment

requirements.title: FDA Stability Requirement
requirements.source_citation: FDA, Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Device Software Functions: Lifecycle Management and Marketing Submission Recommendations pg 27 and Consideration for the use of artificial intelligence to support regulatory decision.. page 4
requirements.raw_text: Model performance shall remain stable and acceptable across heterogeneous clients and participant groups, demonstrating safety and effectiveness for all intended users

requirements.title: Client Data Distribution Characterization
requirements.source_citation: FL Survey; FDA Participant Fairness Requirements
requirements.raw_text: The FL program shall characterize client-level data distributions across quantity skew, label/class skew, feature distribution shift, and temporal drift, and quantify the non-IID degree using standardized measures (e.g., Dirichlet ?, distribution divergence) with a versioned registry per client cohort.

requirements.title: Safety Assessment Linkage (SA-01)
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper, p. 33, 35; SAE ARP4761 page 16
requirements.raw_text: Performance metrics and thresholds shall be derived from safety objectives and hazard analysis, with traceable allocation to false negative/false positive risks.

requirements.title: Model Test Evaluation (LM-09)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 71
requirements.raw_text: The trained model shall be evaluated on an independent test set, and verification results shall be documented for certification purposes.

requirements.title: Inference Model Test Evaluation (IMP-08)
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper, p. 77
requirements.raw_text: The deployed inference artifact shall be validated on the test set representative of operational conditions, with documented evidence.

requirements.title: Generalization Bounds (LM-04)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 68,
requirements.raw_text: Quantified generalization bounds with confidence intervals shall be provided to support claims of out?of?sample performance.

requirements.title: Hazard-driven Metrics (SAE ARP)
requirements.source_citation: Requirements; SAE ARP6983 (Metrics for Machine Learning Models to Facilitate SOTIF Analysis in Autonomous Vehicles 2023-01-0829)
requirements.raw_text: The system shall prioritize metric targets according to hazard drivers, explicitly allocating stricter limits to false negatives when warranted by safety analysis.?

requirements.title: Statistical Confidence (FDA)
requirements.source_citation: FDA, Statistical Guidance on Reporting Results from Studies Evaluating Diagnostic Tests - Guidance for Industry and FDA Staff section 5
requirements.raw_text: Two?sided 95% confidence intervals shall be reported for all primary performance estimates used in assurance claims.

requirements.title: ODD Stability (LM-12)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p.72
requirements.raw_text: The trained model shall demonstrate performance stability across the full ODD, including validated operating regions and transitions.

requirements.title: Adverse Condition Robustness (Train, LM-13)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 72
requirements.raw_text: The trained model shall maintain acceptable performance under defined adverse training conditions and perturbations.

requirements.title: Adverse Condition Robustness (Inference, IMP-10)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 77
requirements.raw_text: The inference model shall maintain acceptable performance under defined adverse inference conditions and perturbations.

requirements.title: Robustness Metrics (LM-02)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 68
requirements.raw_text: Robustness and stability metrics with acceptable levels shall be defined, measured, and met prior to release.

requirements.title: Stress Testing (FAA)
requirements.source_citation: FAA Roadmap: p. 16
requirements.raw_text: The system shall undergo stress testing from item to aircraft?level interfaces to detect anomalous behaviors, with corrective actions defined.

requirements.title: Model Explainability
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper p.172-173; MLEAP Project
requirements.raw_text: The AI/ML system shall provide human?understandable and context?relevant explanations of model scope, behavior, outputs, confidence/uncertainty, and limitations for the intended operators, consistent with EASA’s explainability building block.

requirements.title: Feature Attribution Requirements
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper p.172-173; SAE ARP6983
requirements.raw_text: The system shall produce feature attribution explanations with defined fidelity to the underlying model, quantitative stability across runs/seeds, and localization to relevant input regions, with stability tested and reported under controlled repetitions

requirements.title: Configuration Management (CM-01)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 80,
requirements.raw_text: All ML artifacts shall be under configuration management with versioning, change control, and reproducibility procedures.

requirements.title: Metric Stability Monitoring (SA-03)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 39,
requirements.raw_text: Metrics and thresholds shall be continuously monitored to detect degradation or drift against design assumptions.

requirements.title: ODD/Performance Monitoring (EXP-05/06)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 92,
requirements.raw_text: Inputs (ODD bounds) and outputs (performance bounds) shall be monitored in operation with defined alert thresholds.

requirements.title: Output Confidence Monitoring (EXP-07)
requirements.source_citation: EASA CP: p. 92,
requirements.raw_text: Output confidence shall remain within specified operational limits, with alarms and mitigations when exceeded.

requirements.title: Lifecycle Monitoring (FDA TPLC)
requirements.source_citation: FDA, “Artificial intelligence- Enabled Device software functionslifecycle management and marketing submission recommendations” pg  36
requirements.raw_text: The organization shall detect shifts in input data and performance over time and enact defined drift mitigation strategies.

requirements.title: Change Control Plan (FDA PCCP)
requirements.source_citation: FDA, Predetermined Change Control Plans for Medical Devices
requirements.raw_text: A predetermined change control plan (PCCP) shall govern retraining/updates, including regression validation and approval criteria.?

requirements.title: Certification Maintenance (CCMRs, SAE/FAA)
requirements.source_citation:
SAE ARP6983 
FAA-Request to present  AI safety assessment page 10
requirements.raw_text: The system shall support certification maintenance by enabling secure data download, retest, and drift monitoring workflows.

requirements.title: Locked AI Assumption (FAA)
requirements.source_citation: FAA Research Plan: p. 8
requirements.raw_text: Online learning in operation shall be disabled unless explicitly approved and re?assessed under the change control plan.

requirements.title: Model & Data versioning
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept Paper CM-01 p.80; MLOps Best Practices
requirements.raw_text: All ML artifacts (datasets/snapshots and splits, data lineage, code, model binaries, training configurations, environments) shall be under configuration management with version control and change tracking, in line with DO?178C configuration/traceability expectations.

requirements.title: Traceability & Reproducibility
requirements.source_citation: DO-178C; EASA Concept Paper LM-01
requirements.raw_text: The organization shall ensure bidirectional traceability from system/ML requirements to data artifacts, model/code, verification cases/procedures, and objective results to support certification review at the required assurance level.

requirements.title: Communication Efficiency
requirements.source_citation: A Survey for Federated Learning Evaluations: Goals and Measures pg:3, White paper Trustworthiness for AI in Defence page 82,
requirements.raw_text: The federated solution shall meet defined communication efficiency targets compatible with constrained aviation systems.

requirements.title: Operational Feasibility
requirements.source_citation: EASA Concept paper pg 74 IMP-01, Survey for Federated Learning Evaluations: Goals and Measures section IIB, III.B,V.C
requirements.raw_text: Time?to?convergence and real?time constraints shall meet operational feasibility requirements under representative deployment conditions.

requirements.title: Participant Fairness (FDA)
requirements.source_citation: FDA. (2025). Draft Guidance- Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Device Software Functionslifecycle management and marketing submission recommendations page 2, 18
requirements.raw_text: The system shall demonstrate fairness across heterogeneous clients and participant groups, with worst?group performance meeting minimum acceptance criteria.

requirements.title: Benefit Equity
requirements.source_citation: FDA. (2025). Draft Guidance- Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Device Software Functionslifecycle management and marketing submission recommendations pg 4
requirements.raw_text: Benefits of the federated model shall be distributed equitably across clients, with disparities monitored and mitigated.

requirements.title: Privacy Preservation
requirements.source_citation: FDA. (2025). Draft Guidance- Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Device Software Functions lifecycle management and marketing submission recommendations, XII cybersecurity A Survey for Federated Learning Evaluations: Goals and Measures And EASA concept ET-03 page 267
requirements.raw_text: Where applicable, privacy?preserving techniques (e.g., differential privacy) shall be applied to meet documented privacy requirements without violating performance minima.

requirements.title: Attack Protection
requirements.source_citation: EASA-AI-Roadmap-v1.0. pg 3, easa ai roadmap 2, pg 13, EASA concept page 43, FDA. (2025). Draft Guidance page 37, Survey pg 15, 17
requirements.raw_text: The system shall be protected against inference, gradient leakage, poisoning, and backdoor attacks under the defined threat model.?

requirements.title: Robust Aggregation
requirements.source_citation: EASA concept  IS-01-02-03 page 41 (this is already in robustness but here is an aggregation)
requirements.raw_text: Robust aggregation and/or attack detection shall be implemented when threat models require resilience to adversarial clients.

metrics.name: Global Model Accuracy
metrics.notes: EASA Concept Paper: Safety-critical aviation systems (DAL C/D) require high accuracy applied with FHA; FDA guidance requires ?95% for medical devices

metrics.name: Precision (Global)
metrics.notes: SAE ARP6983: Aviation PHM systems should maintain precision ?85% to minimize false alarms; Higher precision (?90%) for critical failures

metrics.name: Recall (Global)
metrics.notes: SAE ARP6983: Recall ?85% ensures detection of critical failures; Aviation safety standards prioritize high recall for failure detection

metrics.name: F1-Score (Global)
metrics.notes: Balanced metric F1?0.85 ensures trade-off between precision/recall for predictive maintenance (NASA C-MAPSS benchmark studies)

metrics.name: RMSE
metrics.notes: NASA C-MAPSS literature: SOTA models achieve RMSE 15-20 cycles; Target ?15 for safety-critical applications (Alomari 2023, Wang 2023)

metrics.name: Score Function (Prognostics)
metrics.notes: PHM08 Competition scoring: Score <1000 is acceptable, <500 is good; Lower scores indicate better early prediction with less late predictions

metrics.name: AUC
metrics.notes: FDA Statistical Guidance: AUC ?0.85 for diagnostic systems; Aviation maintenance models target ?0.90 for reliability

metrics.name: Generalization Gap
metrics.notes: EASA LM-04: Generalization gap between train/test; Safety-critical systems require <3% for certification confidence

metrics.name: Convergence Rate
metrics.notes: FL literature (FedAvg): Typical convergence in 20-50 rounds for IID data; Non-IID aviation data may require up to 50 rounds

metrics.name: Communication Rounds to Convergence
metrics.notes: Communication-efficient FL research: Target <100 rounds for practical deployment; 50 rounds balances accuracy and efficiency

metrics.name: Communication Cost (MB per round)
metrics.notes: FL Survey: Aviation edge devices have bandwidth constraints; Target <50MB/round for satellite/aircraft communication systems

metrics.name: Communication Efficiency Ratio
metrics.notes: Communication efficiency ratio: Compression ratio ?4.5× acceptable (FedCompress); ?10× optimal for bandwidth-constrained aviation

metrics.name: Local Model Variance
metrics.notes: FL Fairness literature: Local variance ?0.10-0.15 indicates acceptable heterogeneity; ?0.10 for safety-critical applications

metrics.name: Inter-Client Performance Std Dev
metrics.notes: FDA Participant Fairness: Performance std dev ?0.05-0.10 across clients ensures equitable model; Aviation requires ?0.05

metrics.name: Statistical Parity Difference
metrics.notes: Fairness literature: Statistical parity difference ?0.10 indicates fairness; ?0.05 for strict fairness in critical systems

metrics.name: Equalized Odds Difference
metrics.notes: Equalized odds: ?0.10 difference acceptable (Hardt 2016); Aviation safety requires ?0.05 for protected groups

metrics.name: Jain Fairness Index
metrics.notes: Jain Fairness Index: JFI ?0.80 indicates fair resource allocation; ?0.90 for high fairness in collaborative FL

metrics.name: Client Contribution (Shapley Value)
metrics.notes: Shapley value fairness: Contribution proportional to data quality/quantity; Ensures fair benefit distribution in FL consortium

metrics.name: KL Divergence
metrics.notes: KL divergence <0.50 indicates similar distributions; <0.30 optimal for federated predictive maintenance to ensure model stability

metrics.name: Privacy Budget (Epsilon)
metrics.notes: Differential Privacy FL: ??10 provides meaningful privacy; ??5 strong privacy (McMahan 2017); Aviation may require ??3

metrics.name: Attack Detection Rate
metrics.notes: Byzantine attack detection: ?80% detection rate minimum; ?90% for safety-critical FL systems (Jebreel 2022)

metrics.name: Byzantine Robustness Score
metrics.notes: Byzantine robustness: Model accuracy degradation <15% under attack; <10% degradation for robust FL (Fang 2020)

metrics.name: Model Update Similarity (Cosine)
metrics.notes: Cosine similarity ?0.90 indicates honest updates; ?0.95 for strict Byzantine detection (Multi-Krum baseline)

metrics.name: Drift Detection (KS p-value)
metrics.notes: KS test: p<0.01 indicates significant drift; Adaptive threshold based on rolling window (ADDM method, Baier 2022)

metrics.name: Data Quality Score
metrics.notes: EASA DQR, Data quality score ?0.70 acceptable; ?0.85 for high-quality aviation training data

metrics.name: ODD Coverage Percentage
metrics.notes: ISO/PAS 21448 SOTIF: ODD coverage ?85% minimum; ?95% for comprehensive coverage in safety-critical systems

metrics.name: Adversarial Robustness (ASR)
metrics.notes: Adversarial robustness: Attack success rate <30% acceptable; <20% for robust models (FGSM/PGD attacks benchmark)

metrics.name: Calibration Error (ECE)
metrics.notes: Calibration: ECE ?0.10 indicates well-calibrated model; ?0.05 for safety-critical aviation decisions (Guo 2017)

metrics.name: Confidence Interval Width (95% CI)
metrics.notes: FDA 95% CI: Confidence interval width ?0.10 for performance metrics ensures statistical reliability

metrics.name: Time to Convergence (seconds)
metrics.notes: Operational feasibility: Training time <2 hours (7200s) per round; <1 hour optimal for practical FL deployment

metrics.name: Model Explainability Score (SHAP)
metrics.notes: EASA Explainability, SHAP-based explanations should cover ?60% of model decision; ?70% for interpretable models

metrics.name: Feature Attribution Stability
metrics.notes: Feature attribution stability: Consistency ?0.75 across multiple runs; ?0.85 for reliable explanations (LIME/SHAP)

metrics.name: Model Version Consistency
metrics.notes: MLOps best practices: Version match rate ?95% for reproducibility; ?98% for certification-grade traceability

metrics.name: Reproducibility Score
metrics.notes: DO-178C/EASA CM-01, Full reproducibility score ?0.90; ?0.95 for airborne software development assurance

metrics.name: Local Accuracy Variance
metrics.notes: Client fairness: Local accuracy variance ?0.15 indicates fair learning; ?0.10 for equitable FL systems

metrics.name: Client Dropout Tolerance
metrics.notes: FL reliability: Model tolerates ?70% client dropout; ?80% tolerance for robust aviation FL systems

metrics.name: Memory Footprint (MB)
metrics.notes: Edge computing constraints: Model size ?1024MB for aircraft systems; ?2048MB maximum for embedded devices

metrics.name: Inference Latency (ms)
metrics.notes: Real-time requirements: Inference latency ?50ms for predictive maintenance alerts; ?100ms acceptable for monitoring

metrics.name: False Positive Rate
metrics.notes: Safety-critical: FPR ?0.05-0.10 minimizes false alarms while maintaining detection capability

metrics.name: False Negative Rate
metrics.notes: Safety-critical: FNR ?0.05-0.10 ensures critical failures are not missed; Lower FNR prioritized for aviation safety

params.objective: Establish performance baseline with centralized training on full C-MAPSS dataset
params.dataset_configuration: Full C-MAPSS (FD001, FD002, FD003, FD004); 80/10/10 train/val/test split

params.objective: Evaluate FL performance with balanced IID data distribution across clients
params.dataset_configuration: 10 clients, each with equal portion of C-MAPSS data; Random balanced split
params.fl_configuration: FedAvg; 10 clients; 100% participation; E=5 local epochs; lr=0.001

params.objective: Test FL performance with non-IID quantity skew (clients have different data amounts)
params.dataset_configuration: 10 clients with Dirichlet(?=0.5) distribution; Some clients have 10× more data

params.objective: Test FL performance with non-IID label skew (clients have different failure mode distributions)
params.dataset_configuration: 10 clients with failure mode partitioning; Each client has 1-2 failure modes dominant

params.objective: Measure communication overhead and efficiency of FL vs centralized
params.dataset_configuration: Same as T2 with communication logging
params.success_criteria: Communication cost ?50 MB/round; Efficiency ratio ?5×; Convergence time ?2 hours

params.objective: Test robustness against Byzantine attacks (label-flipping, gradient manipulation)
params.dataset_configuration: T2 setup + 20% malicious clients with label-flipping (10%) and gradient manipulation
params.success_criteria: Attack detection ?0.85; Model accuracy degradation ?15% under attack

params.objective: Evaluate privacy-utility trade-off with different ? values
params.fl_configuration: DP-FedAvg with Gaussian noise; Clipping threshold C=1.0; ?=10^-5

params.objective: Test model convergence and performance with varying client dropout rates
params.fl_configuration: FedAvg with asynchronous updates; Straggler threshold=2× median time
params.success_criteria: Model converges with ?70% dropout; Performance degradation ?10%

params.objective: Monitor and detect concept drift, test adaptation strategies
params.dataset_configuration: Sequential training with FD001?FD002 transition to simulate operational condition change
params.fl_configuration: FedAvg with drift detection (KS test every 10 rounds); Retrain threshold p<0.01
params.success_criteria: Drift detected within 5 rounds of change; Adaptation recovers accuracy within 10 rounds

params.objective: Evaluate fairness metrics across clients with heterogeneous data
params.dataset_configuration: T3 setup with detailed per-client performance tracking

params.objective: Analyze model interpretability using SHAP/LIME for FL vs centralized
params.dataset_configuration: T1 and T2 with SHAP value computation for top 10 features
params.fl_configuration: FedAvg + SHAP computation on aggregated model
params.success_criteria: SHAP consistency ?0.75; Top-5 features match across centralized/federated

params.objective: Validate complete framework with all requirements on realistic aviation scenario
params.dataset_configuration: T3 + T5 + T6 + T7 combined; Realistic 20-client aviation fleet scenario
params.fl_configuration: FedAvg + Multi-Krum + DP (?=5) + Compression + Fairness-aware aggregation
params.success_criteria: All metric thresholds met; System operates within aviation safety requirements
